Black offers to swap off his problematic lsb, not really expecting the offer to be accepted.

White proceeds with his slow build-up against Black's castled king.
The N quickly returns from the edge of the board but to what purpose?
Now White commits to a Kingside attack, happy to leave his King in the middle of the board behind his advanced wall of white-squared pawns.
A fairly standard manoeuvre, releasing the pin.  In this position there is also the longer term hope of action on the e-file.
Even though this helps White to clear the file for his rook, I saw no compelling reason not ot play this now.  If I didn't take the pawn, it could advance to h6 embarrassing my dsb.
